Open in a new tabRates of Skin Cancer Development by Transplanted Organ Type
Patients with liver transplants developed a first skin cancer after transplant at a lower rate compared with heart, lung, or kidney recipients (χ2 test, 25.6; df, 4; P < .001) (Figure 1A).
After the development of a first skin cancer, patients were far more likely to develop a second and third skin cancer than to experience the competing risk of death (Figure 2 and Figure 3).

Open in a new tabRates of Skin Cancer Development by Age at Transplant
After transplant, there was a steady increase in the risk of first skin cancer risk among all age groups (Figure 1B).

Among patients who survived to develop a second skin cancer, there was very low mortality, and nearly 100% went on to develop a third skin cancer across all organ types and all transplant age groups (Figure 3).Voriconazole Exposure
A total of 318 patients had posttransplant exposure to voriconazole, 190 of whom were lung recipients.

Patients with liver transplants developed a first skin cancer after transplant at a lower rate compared with heart, lung, or kidney recipients (χ2 test, 25.6; df, 4; P < .001) (Figure 1A).
After the development of a first skin cancer, patients were far more likely to develop a second and third skin cancer than to experience the competing risk of death (Figure 2 and Figure 3).

Open in a new tabRates of Skin Cancer Development by Age at Transplant
After transplant, there was a steady increase in the risk of first skin cancer risk among all age groups (Figure 1B).

Among patients who survived to develop a second skin cancer, there was very low mortality, and nearly 100% went on to develop a third skin cancer across all organ types and all transplant age groups (Figure 3).Voriconazole Exposure
A total of 318 patients had posttransplant exposure to voriconazole, 190 of whom were lung recipients.

Rates of Skin Cancer Development by Transplanted Organ Type
Patients with liver transplants developed a first skin cancer after transplant at a lower rate compared with heart, lung, or kidney recipients (χ2 test, 25.6; df, 4; P < .001) (Figure 1A).
After the development of a first skin cancer, patients were far more likely to develop a second and third skin cancer than to experience the competing risk of death (Figure 2 and Figure 3).
Patients with liver transplants developed a first skin cancer after transplant at a lower rate compared with heart, lung, or kidney recipients (χ2 test, 25.6; df, 4; P < .001) (Figure 1A).
After the development of a first skin cancer, patients were far more likely to develop a second and third skin cancer than to experience the competing risk of death (Figure 2 and Figure 3).

Rates of Skin Cancer Development by Age at Transplant
After transplant, there was a steady increase in the risk of first skin cancer risk among all age groups (Figure 1B).

Among patients who survived to develop a second skin cancer, there was very low mortality, and nearly 100% went on to develop a third skin cancer across all organ types and all transplant age groups (Figure 3).
After transplant, there was a steady increase in the risk of first skin cancer risk among all age groups (Figure 1B).

Among patients who survived to develop a second skin cancer, there was very low mortality, and nearly 100% went on to develop a third skin cancer across all organ types and all transplant age groups (Figure 3).
